nodes.bodyText: This is not a TODO. The code is optimal (to some degree) at this point. The comment is made so that no one wants to try generalize it more and end up loosing performance.
Consider rewriting this to stress the actual goal.

toUnsignedLong(getInt(left, 0)) is different than getRawLong(left, 0).
One expect 32 bits storage space, while other expects 64 bits.
How does it work?

toUnsignedLong(getInt(left, 0)) does:

get low 32-bits from left. If we replace 0 with 3 then the high-most bit (sign) is erased
cast them to long as unsigned

while getRawLong(left, 0) gets low 64 bits without any logic.
This is by no mean a replacement for the above. The actual sign logic and making 32-bit values is done inside the multiply method
I guess this if supposed to be an optimization. Do you say that it is opposite?

Every if in the code enables the branch prediction mechanism (an probably many more) in CPU. Sometimes it is better to make few more ops than introduce branch programming. This appears to be the case since the code inside the brackets is fairly small.
And this is not the case in the generalized multiply method.
At least that what benchmarks tell me.
How is this being measured? What benchmarks are you trying? When I wrote it this way it was precisely because some benchmarks indicated it was faster this way.

BenchmarkDecimalOperators.
This has been discussed in https://prestosql.slack.com/archives/CP1MUNEUX/p1597832153058600.
The generic 128x128 bit method is faster with ifs, as well as 128x64 one (which is removed in this PR).
The 64x64 one is in turn faster without any branches.
Any chance for vectorization in 64x64 in java 11?

TLDR - no
This is actually an extremely interesting subject. I discussed it with Karol heavily.
Java will (with a little bit of help) use SIMD registers in certain situations. Unfortunately it requires operating on arrays, not single values like we do here. Making operators and functions use entire columns will likely help.
So we only need to reimplement half of core presto to make it work. Might seems a little excessive at this point though.
This - https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/338 - may help.
